Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Managing Impacts of Global Transport of Atmosphere-Surface Exchangeable Pollutants in the Context of Global Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Toxic pollutants that pass readily in both directions between the atmosphere and environmental surfaces exhibit three characteristic tendencies when they are emitted to the environment: resistance to rapid degradation, accumulation in organic-rich surface reservoirs, and semivolatility causing re-emission to the atmosphere. These pollutants, termed "Atmosphere-Surface Exchangeable Pollutants" or ASEPs, are emitted to the environment through human activities, are transported and "processed" in the environment, and are then deposited where they may harm humans and wildlife, often in locations distant from their original use or release. Incomplete understanding of the dynamic behavior of these pollutants in the environment has resulted in efforts to regulate them that do not fully protect human and ecosystem health from risks. The human system, including sociopolitical activities, cultural perspectives, and socioeconomic activity resulting in emission of the pollutants into the environment and other environmental stressors, the biogeochemical cycling of the pollutants in the global environment, and the impairment of ecosystem services that result from this cycling comprise the coupled human-natural system of study. The objective of this study is to probe the complex dynamics and feedbacks within the system and to identify critical social adaptations and governance advancements required to address the challenges to sustainability posed by these chemicals. Because emissions of these pollutants occur throughout the world and they tend to move northward in cycles of re-volatilization and deposition, resource managers face a particularly difficult challenge in addressing concerns related to this form of contamination. To identify ways in which the regulation of these chemicals can be improved, simulate their global transport will be simulated under differing future climate and land cover/land use scenarios to estimate amounts sequestered in and re-emitted from ecosystems. The project team will quantify the economic costs in the United States caused by exposure to these chemicals and analyze efforts to adaptively manage these chemicals at scales ranging from local to global. The Laurentian Great Lakes will provide the geographical focus for nested analysis of social adaption and governance.


The project focuses on pollutants that travel long distances in the atmosphere and cause harm to humans and ecosystems far from the locations where they were emitted. The characteristics of atmosphere足 surface exchangeable pollutants lead to a separation in space and time between use and harmful impacts. These pollutants are released into the environment through human activities that yield economic benefits, but the economic costs of damage to human health and environmental impacts are often borne by other segments of society. Because the chemicals cross political boundaries, efforts to address any concerns are complex. The project team will examine details of the environmental cycling of these pollutants (how, where and when they cycle between the air and the Earth surface) that currently impede our ability to model their global transport and fate, and thus inform policy decision-making. They will also assess the economic damages caused in the United States by these pollutants. By studying the coupled human足 natural system involving these chemicals, this project will improve our understanding of sustainable means of production, use and governance of a class of pollutants. Public outreach and distributed K足 college education activities, and partnering between researchers, educators, stakeholders, and decision足 makers, will promote incorporation of research results into learning, education, and governance. This project brings together a diverse group of natural and social scientists from four academic institutions to study the problem of these pollutants in a more holistic fashion than has ever been attempted to date, and may serve as a model for studying other classes of substances in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Toxic pollutants that pass readily in both directions between the atmosphere and environmental surfaces, herein called atmosphere-surface exchangeable pollutants or ASEPs, exhibit three characteristic tendencies when they are emitted to the environment: resistance to rapid degradation, accumulation in organic-rich surface reservoirs, and semivolatility causing secondary emission to the atmosphere.  For these chemicals it is unclear if we have already passed the planetary boundary, the safe operating space for humanity with respect to the Earth system. ASEPs are emitted to the environment through human activities, are transported and “processed” in the environment, and are then deposited where they may adversely impact humans and wildlife, often in locations distant from their original use, through impacts on services that ecosystems provide to humans such as safe air, water, and food. The system of humans, ASEPs, the natural environment, and their couplings through anthropogenic stressors (e.g., emission, climate and land use change) and ecosystem services provided by nature is the domain of this project. The characteristic tendencies of ASEPs lead to separation in space and time of ASEP use and harmful impacts. Incomplete understanding of the separation of use and impacts has led to forms of governance that do not fully protect human and ecosystem health from ASEP risks.

Intellectual Merit. Our objective was to probe the complex dynamics and feedbacks within the system, and to identify critical social adaptations and governance advancements required to address the challenges to sustainability posed by three ASEP compound/classes in the context of global change: mercury, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and polychlorinated biphenyls. Although thousands of ASEPs have been or are presently sold globally, these ASEP compound/classes were selected for first examination because they have a legacy of usage of six decades and more. Study of influences of scale on governance and adaptation will be nested within the Laurentian Great Lakes region. The over-arching questions we posed were: How will future environmental ASEP cycling be affected by changes in primary and secondary emissions, land use/land cover, and climate, and how can governance and adaptation be strengthened to maximize sustainability in coming decades? This study included three research, education and capacity-building components. The first component examined the dynamic natural system of ASEPs through a) the creation of standardized databases of terrestrial reservoirs and primary and secondary emissions and b) the use of a global atmospheric chemical transport and Great Lakes region models to estimate ASEP deposition, sequestration, re-emission, and bioaccumulation in fish in coming decades under specific emission, land use and climate change scenarios. The second component used patterns of deposition predicted by the atmospheric chemical transport model to analyze health and economic effects in regions of the U.S. related to consumption of mercury-contaminated fish. The third component used efforts to address ASEP-related concerns in the Great Lakes to assess the capacity of the emerging, nested system of governance to address those concerns and to identify ways to improve that capacity. The project supported nine of twelve NSF-wide SEES Investment Area Objectives.

Broader Impacts. The project advanced discovery and promoted teaching, training, and learning through development of research-based STEM K-8/public outreach educational activities related to ASEPs, and through involvement of college students through a reciprocal mentoring model. It created partnerships between researchers and K-college educators, including the Keweenaw Bay Ojibwa Community College, to incorporate research into learning and education. The project further broadened participation of underrepresented groups through campus visits such as three workshops, and collaboration with the Keweenaw Bay Indian Community. It enhanced infrastructure for research and education through partnering with eleven organizations representative of the jurisdictions and scales of the research and education activities, and disseminated to enhance scientific understanding by presenting research results and education activities in formats useful to partnering organizations.  The project benefitted society through partnering with academic scientists, members of staff of State/Provincial and Federal agencies, and Tribes, through analysis and synthesis of research results in ways that are understandable/useful for non-scientists, and by providing information for governance formulation.
